notesStmt.note: On the back inside flyleaf are descriptive notes on the manuscript, indicating that Thomas M. Izbicki identified it as Raymond of Peñafort's Summa de Poentitentia in a letter of July 8, 1980

Fol. 31 has been cut and repaired. Two leaves from Book I are loose at the beginning of the manuscript. Some discoloration to leaves, with a number of final leaves in the manuscript curling at the corners.

msIdentifier.collection: John Frederick Lewis Collection of European Manuscripts

msContents.summary: This manuscript is a 13th-century copy from France of Raymond of Penafort's (c. 1175 - 1275) Summa de casibus poenitentia (Treatise on the Cases of Penance). Raymond was a member of the Dominican Order, and an authority on the subject of canon law. His Summa de casibus poenitentia (Treatise on the Cases of Penance), a manual of canon law for confessors, was intended for use in determining the type and amount of penance a person should receive for a specific crime or sinful act. The gloss was composed by William of Rennes, a contemporary of Raymond. His gloss often accompanies the text of the Summa de casibus poenitentia.

msItem.title: Book I, Summa de Poenitentia, beginning and ending imperfectly
msItem.incipit: seruitutis [in]debite impe[n]sa mun[us] a li[n]gua fauor i. q. i
msItem.explicit: nec diffe[ren]do p[ro]p[ter] hoc suplturam s[ed] implorando off[iciu]m epi[scopi] [ue]l s[upe]rioris ex de sy[mon] [con]st[itutione] ad ap[ostolorum] [60v]

msItem.title: Book II, Summa de Poenitentia, beginning and ending imperfectly
msItem.incipit: consule[n]do nocendo uictum s[u]btrahendo de primo io in ca. iii
msItem.explicit: Ex s[e]c[un]do uero [e]s[t] dfinat colligitur q[uod] [etiam] siduxit in consuetudine[m] d[ebet] a[d]mo[neri] [109v]

msItem.title: Book III, Summa de Poenitentia, beginning and ending imperfectly
msItem.incipit: no[n] uinolentum no[n] p[er]cussorum s[ed] modestum no[n] litigiosum no[n] cupidum sue domui bene p[re]positum
msItem.explicit: Non e[t]i[am] s[u]bt[erfugi] quo minus a[n]nu[ciarem] omne co[n]silium dicit[ur] [116v]

supportDesc.extent: i+116+i; 256 x 170 mm bound to 269 x 190 mm
supportDesc.foliation: Modern foliation in pencil, upper right recto

collation.p: Uncertain; binding is tight and catchwords are inconsistent

p.catchwords: Occasional catchwords, inconsistent, many are trimmed

layoutDesc.layout: Two loose leaves from the MS slipped in before flyleaf; written area: 175 x 118 mm; 2 columns of 40 lines, lead point ruling; the primary text is in a slightly larger script and always runs in the left column with the gloss to the right; the opening pages to each book have been excised, leaving relatively little decoration: flourished initials in red and blue begin rubricated chapter openings and books are designated in red and blue roman initials in the upper margins; the original foliation is visible in the upper left verso corners, beginning from fol. i with each book; lightly annotated throughout.

decoDesc.decoNote: Occasional blue and red initials; red underlining and blue and red paragraph markings throughout; math equations in pencil appear in the margins of ff. 52v and 116 v.

binding.p: Modern vellum over board with leather thongs; inscription in the inner front cover identifies it as French from the thirteenth century; written in ink on spine: "TREATISE ON CANON LAW."
